content:
The film, starring James wrap-span">Norton, wrap-span">Vanessa wrap-span">Kirby and Peter Sarsgaard, wrap-span">portrays wrap-span">journalism as a type of wrap-span">heroism

WALKING THROUGH rural Ukraine in 1932, having wrap-span">eluded his Communist Party chaperone, wrap-span">Gareth wrap-span">Jones witnessed disturbing wrap-span">deprivation. People were starving, fighting each other tooth and wrap-span">nail for a single wrap-span">loaf of bread. Bodies lay in the street until they were piled up and carted away on wrap-span">wagons. While its own citizens suffered, the Soviet Union was continuing to export wrap-span">grain, projecting an image of wrap-span">prosperity to the West. Recent wrap-span">estimates have suggested that around 4m people wrap-span">perished in 1932 and 1933, around 13% of the wrap-span">Ukrainian population, in what is known today as the Holodomor (“killing by hunger”). At the time, though, few believed wrap-span">Jones’s reports; many politicians, wrap-span">diplomats and journalists tried to wrap-span">discredit him.

In “Mr. wrap-span">Jones”, a feature film which wrap-span">premiered at the Berlinale, the journalist’s search for the truth makes for wrap-span">stylish and compelling historical drama. It opens with wrap-span">Jones (played with wrap-span">sincerity and wrap-span">conviction by James wrap-span">Norton) presciently explaining the danger of Germany’s National wrap-span">Socialist party to wrap-span">Lloyd George, his boss at the Foreign Office, and his colleagues. They wrap-span">scoff at this bold young man. Before he can argue that the economic forecasts released by the Soviet Union are also a cause for concern, he is made wrap-span">redundant as a result of budget cuts. 

wrap-span">Jones decides to wrap-span">investigate the matter himself, and, despite not having an editor to recommend him, talks his way into getting a press visa for the wrap-span">USSR. He refuses to accept the same political wrap-span">restrictions as the other journalists he meets in Moscow: their reports, wrap-span">conforming to the wrap-span">Pravda version of the truth, claim that the economy is thriving and that collectivisation has been a wrap-span">boon to farmers. What he discovers, despite the efforts of Soviet officials to limit his information-gathering trips, is quite the opposite. “Mr. wrap-span">Jones” wrap-span">depicts the wrap-span">desperation, violence and wrap-span">cannibalism that wrap-span">Ukrainians were driven to, yet avoids wrap-span">sensationalism or wrap-span">gratuitous wrap-span">horrors. 

The film’s wrap-span">villain is not some Soviet heavy, but wrap-span">Walter Duranty (Peter Sarsgaard), the wrap-span">Pulitzer prize-winning Moscow wrap-span">bureau chief of the New York Times . He, along with other members of the Western press, wrap-span">conspires to keep this wrap-span">tragedy under wraps, and is often more interested in the chemical and sexual highs that 1930s expat life in Moscow could offer. The real-life Duranty published an article wrap-span">entitled “Russians Hungry, But Not Starving” which made light of wrap-span">Jones’s reporting. (He wrote that “it appeared that [wrap-span">Jones] had made a 40-mile walk through villages in the neighbourhood of wrap-span">Kharkov and had found the conditions sad”; the New York Times has since wrap-span">repudiated his coverage .) In the film, he views staying wrap-span">silent on the wrap-span">horrors of wrap-span">authoritarianism as an wrap-span">expedient part of the business of reporting from Russia. wrap-span">Ada wrap-span">Brooks (wrap-span">Vanessa wrap-span">Kirby), the Times ’s star reporter, is less wrap-span">convinced, but both defend the wrap-span">USSR’s actions, insisting that the long-term project may demand some short-term wrap-span">distress. The truth, in their view, can be shaped.

wrap-span">Jones, as the film’s wrap-span">moral lead, explains the shortcomings of this attitude in scenes and dialogue that can be rather self-wrap-span">conscious. He is wrap-span">convinced that finding out and publicising wrap-span">incontrovertible facts will lead to action, and do the world good. Unlike the staff journalists, whose wrap-span">livelihood lies in Moscow and who must therefore keep the authorities happy, in the film wrap-span">Jones’s role as a wrap-span">freelance reporter offers him a kind of independence that allows him to devote himself to the wrap-span">pursuit of the truth.

Although he does not manage to persuade Duranty, wrap-span">Jones does wrap-span">convince another high-wrap-span">profile writer of the ills of the wrap-span">USSR: Eric wrap-span">Blair, better known as George wrap-span">Orwell. Scenes of wrap-span">Orwell in front of his wrap-span">typewriter at work on “Animal Farm” are wrap-span">interspersed wrap-span">anachronistically—the novel was written 10 years later—throughout the film. These wrap-span">interludes show wrap-span">Blair becoming wrap-span">noticeably more critical of wrap-span">authoritarian power after the two writers meet and discuss what wrap-span">Jones saw in Ukraine. It is a wrap-span">clunky wrap-span">narrative device, suggesting that the film-makers did not have faith in viewers to understand the evils of wrap-span">totalitarian wrap-span">censorship without an wrap-span">Orwellian name-drop.

A few years after the events wrap-span">depicted in the film, just before his 30th birthday, wrap-span">Jones was murdered in wrap-span">Mongolia by mercenaries connected to the wrap-span">KGB. “Mr. wrap-span">Jones” holds its subject up as a model for reporters everywhere, even if at times it turns him and other characters into wrap-span">ciphers. Any wrap-span">hesitation, fear or even wrap-span">cowardice wrap-span">Jones might have shown is absent from this account. Still, at a time when wrap-span">journalism is the subject of wrap-span">scorn and calumnies, the film points out that the wrap-span">profession can demand wrap-span">righteousness, wrap-span">bravery and even wrap-span">heroism.

当被问到如果能够“遁形”一天的话他会做什么时，布莱尔渴望过一种更加正常的生活。 他说他愿意“在街道上散散步，去酒馆转转……就是过一种完全正常的生活而已。”

我也借那个机会祝贺北京大学和托尼布莱尔信仰基金会合作开设了关于“信仰与全球化”的课程。

我们可以使用内部类来做到这一点，但是它们的用法是如此笨拙，以致于有时候其所带来的效果看起来似乎比要解决的问题还糟糕。

我听见了许多人的谗谤，四围都是惊吓。 他们一同商议攻击我的时候，就图谋要害我的性命。
This is one of the ways that science and the law conspire to make the world a safer and better place to live.
这就是科学和法律如何协作使得我们生活的世界成为一个更加安全适于我们居住的地方了。

ex: vt. 说服；使确信，使信服
eg2: It requires a lot of talking to  him.
要说服他很费口舌。
But how do you  someone to live this small?
但是你怎么能说服这些人住进这些小房子里呢？
She or he should be able to convince you of stupid decisions and future consequences.
她或者他应该能够说服你的愚蠢决定和后面不堪设想的后果。

ex: n. 怯懦；胆小
vt. 描述；描画
eg2: An Activity diagram must be owned by an Activity and must fully and exclusively  the semantics of that Activity.
一个活动图必须被一个活动所拥有，并且必须全面的和专有的描述该活动的语义学；
You could also use it as a place to gather diagrams from the more detailed models of a solution, so that you can depict various architecturally significant viewpoints of that solution.
您还能够将它用作一个从解决方案的细节模型中收集图的地方，从而您就能够描述那个解决方案的各种各样的架构的重要观点。
You may not know this but women CAN get highly aroused even with just words, especially those that depict what you plan to do to them in bed.
你可能不知道这点，但脏话确实能够非常好地带动女性的情绪，特别是那些描述你即将在床上要做的动作的脏话。

Title: “Mr. Jones” tells the story of the man who exposed the Ukrainian famine
